title: 110_hr5898
content: The "Silver Alert Grant Program Act of 2008" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The purposes of the Act are outlined in section 2. The Act aims to create a grant program to establish and improve State-administered notification systems for finding missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia-related illnesses. It also aims to promote best practices for Silver Alert systems and increase awareness about the need for coordination. The Act aims to establish grant programs for State-administered notification systems to find missing seniors with Alzheimer's and dementia. It also promotes best practices for Silver Alert systems and emphasizes the importance of coordinated efforts to locate missing individuals quickly for safe reunification with their families. The Act emphasizes the importance of coordinated efforts to locate missing individuals quickly for safe reunification with their families. According to the Congress, up to 5,000,000 people in the US may have Alzheimer's disease, with the risk increasing with age. Data shows that 1 in 8 individuals over 65 have the disease, and a new case is reported every 71 seconds. The aging population, particularly the baby boomer generation, will lead to a rise in Alzheimer's disease cases. The Alzheimer's Association estimates that over 60% of patients with the disease will wander away from their care facilities. This illness causes confusion and disorientation in its victims. States like Colorado, Illinois, Michigan, North Carolina, and Texas have implemented notification systems similar to the Amber Alert for missing seniors with dementia-related illnesses. Timely dissemination of information to law enforcement and authorities has proven effective in these states. The timely dissemination of information about missing individuals increases the chances of locating them. Some states have implemented systems similar to the Amber Alert for missing seniors with dementia. Congress believes that Silver Alert systems should have clear criteria to avoid frequent notifications. Silver Alert criteria: notifications not lessened by frequency, age not sole factor, for individuals incapable of personal care decisions, initiated by recent contact person. The Silver Alert criteria emphasize protecting the privacy and dignity of missing individuals, encouraging training for law enforcement on locating those with Alzheimer's disease. The Federal Government can help prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses by coordinating with State officials and local entities in the Missing Alzheimer's Disease Patient Alert Program. The Federal Government aims to prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses by assisting States in establishing, implementing, and improving Silver Alert systems. The Silver Alert System Grant Program aims to assist States in establishing, implementing, and improving systems to prevent injuries and loss of life among individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The Attorney General can award grants to States to establish or improve Silver Alert systems. Each grant is for a one-year period and must be at least $100,000. Regulations must be in place within one year. The Attorney General can award grants to States for Silver Alert systems, with each grant being at least $100,000. Regulations must be established within one year, including eligibility criteria and selection criteria for States. $5,600,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2009 to 2013. SEC. 5. ANNUAL REPORT ON SILVER ALERT SYSTEMS. The Attorney General must provide an annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems, listing states with such systems and detailing the number of alerts issued, individuals located successfully, and the average time taken to locate them. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes information on the criteria for issuing alerts, the process of dissemination, costs, cross-state missing individuals, and actions taken to protect privacy and dignity. The annual report to Congress on Silver Alert systems includes details on the criteria for issuing alerts, dissemination process, costs, cross-state missing individuals, privacy protection, and communication improvements among families, caregivers, law enforcement, and other authorities. Additionally, the report may include any other relevant information determined by the Attorney General. The Silver Alert system is a State-administered notification system to locate missing individuals with Alzheimer's disease and other dementia-related illnesses. The term "State" refers to various regions within the United States and its territories.
